April 17, 2016: Fiction
FOOL ME ONCE, by Harlan Coben. (Dutton.) A retired Army helicopter pilot faces
combat-related nightmares and mysteries concerning the deaths of her husband and
sister.
THE NEST, by Cynthia D'Aprix Sweeney. (Ecco/HarperCollins.) Siblings in a
dysfunctional New York family must grapple with a reduced inheritance.
PRIVATE PARIS, by James Patterson and Mark Sullivan. (Little, Brown.) Jack
Morgan, the head of the Private global investigative agency, probes the murders of
members of the French cultural elite.
JOURNEY TO MUNICH, by Jacqueline Winspear. (Harper/HarperCollins.) In 1938,
the psychologist Maisie Dobbs travels to Germany to impersonate the daughter of a
prisoner.
THE NIGHTINGALE, by Kristin Hannah. (St. Martin's.) Two sisters in World War II
France: one struggling to survive in the countryside, the other joining the Resistance
in Paris.
ALL THE LIGHT WE CANNOT SEE, by Anthony Doerr. (Scribner.) The lives of a
blind French girl and a gadget-obsessed German boy before and during World War II.
THE SUMMER BEFORE THE WAR, by Helen Simonson. (Random House.) Life in
Sussex, England, at the beginning of World War I.
THE GIRL ON THE TRAIN, by Paula Hawkins. (Riverhead.) A psychological thriller
set in the environs of London.
PROPERTY OF A NOBLEWOMAN, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte.) Two New Yorkers
reconstruct the history of a young woman and a love affair at the time of World War II.
BRUSH OF WINGS, by Karen Kingsbury. (Howard.) Book 3 in the Angels Walking
series.
OFF THE GRID, by C. J. Box. (Putnam.) The 16th Joe Pickett novel features Nate
Romanowski and a search for a domestic terror cell.
AFTER YOU, by Jojo Moyes. (Pamela Dorman/Viking.) In a sequel to “Me Before
You,” Louisa Clark tries to put her life back together after the death of Will Traynor.
THE OTHER SIDE OF SILENCE, by Philip Kerr. (Marian Wood/Putnam.) Ten years
after the end of World War II, Bernie Gunther, now a concierge at a Cap Ferrat hotel,
becomes a bridge buddy of Somerset Maugham, at whose home he meets Anthony
Blunt and Guy Burgess.
THE ANCIENT MINSTREL, by Jim Harrison. (Grove.) Three novellas by the poet and
novelist, who died in March.
April 17, 2016
Non-Fiction
WHEN BREATH BECOMES AIR, by Paul Kalanithi. (Random House.) A memoir
by a physician who received a diagnosis of Stage IV lung cancer at the age of 36.
LUST AND WONDER, by Augusten Burroughs. (St. Martin's.) Burroughs's post-
rehab love life in 1990s New York City, and its eventual happy ending.
SEVEN BRIEF LESSONS ON PHYSICS, by Carlo Rovelli. (Riverhead.) An
introduction to modern physics.
GIRLS AND SEX, by Peggy Orenstein. (Harper/HarperCollins.) Interviews with
more than 70 teenagers shed light on their experience of sexuality.
BETWEEN THE WORLD AND ME, by Ta-Nehisi Coates. (Spiegel & Grau.) A
meditation on race in America; winner of the National Book Award.
DARK MONEY, by Jane Mayer. (Doubleday.) An account of how the Koch
brothers and other super-wealthy donors deployed their money to change
American politics.
SMARTER FASTER BETTER, by Charles Duhigg. (Random House.) The science
of productivity, from the author of "The Power of Habit."
THE IMMORTAL IRISHMAN, by Timothy Egan. (Houghton Mifflin Harcourt.) The
life of Thomas Francis Meagher, an Irish revolutionary who fled to America and
became the general of New York’s Irish Brigade during the Civil War.
BEING MORTAL, by Atul Gawande. (Metropolitan/Holt.) The surgeon and New
Yorker writer considers how doctors fail patients at the end of life and how they
can do better.
SPAIN IN OUR HEARTS, by Adam Hochschild. (Houghton Mifflin Harcourt.)
Americans who fought in and wrote about the Spanish Civil War.
BACK FROM THE DEAD, by Bill Walton. (Simon & Schuster.) An autobiography
of the former basketball player (and Deadhead), who has struggled with injuries.
THE LEGENDS CLUB, by John Feinstein. (Doubleday.) A sportswriter’s account
of three famous basketball coaches and their rivalry.
EVICTED, by Matthew Desmond. (Crown.) How poor people repeatedly lose their
homes while landlords profit.
ORIGINALS, by Adam Grant. (Viking.) A Wharton School professor argues that
innovators are made, not born, and offers suggestions for how to become one.
AMERICAN GIRLS, by Nancy Jo Sales. (Knopf.) How social media has changed
the way girls grow up.
